title: PSTAT 5H Guest Lecture
text:
Model selection
Model selection refers to choosing one of several candidate models for a set of data.

have \(K\) candidate models \(\{M_1, M_2, \dots, M_K\}\)
goal is to select a ‘best’ model \(M^* \in \{M_1, M_2, \dots, M_K\}\)

title: PSTAT 5H Guest Lecture
text:
Linear models
A linear model says that the mean of a variable of interest \(Y\) is linear in \(p\) predictors \(X_1, \dots, X_p\):
\[
\mathbb{E}Y = \beta_0 + \beta_1 X_1 + \beta_2 X_2 + \dots + \beta_p X_p
\]

For example, with a single predictor:



Figure from Tukey (1977).

title: PSTAT 5H Guest Lecture
text:
In higher dimensions
When \(p > 1\) , the linear model describes the mean of \(Y\) as lying on a plane in \(p\)-dimensional space.

To fit the model to data, one needs at least \(p + 1\) data points.

title: PSTAT 5H Guest Lecture
text:
Subset selection
The classical model selection problem is subset selection or variable selection in the linear model.

choose a subset \(S \subset \{X_1, \dots, X_p\}\) that gives the ‘best’ linear model
in other words, choose the best collection of predictors
\(2^p\) possible choices

title: PSTAT 5H Guest Lecture
text:
Regularization
A clever solution is to constrain the linear coefficients \(\beta_1, \beta_2, \dots, \beta_p\) using a sparsity-inducing constraint: a condition that requires some number of \(\beta_j\)’s to be set to zero when the values are estimated.

This produces a model like
\[
\mathbb{E}Y = \beta_0 + \color{red}{0 X_1} + \beta_2 X_2 + \cdots + \color{red}{0 X_p}
\]
and thereby performs ‘automatic’ subset selection.

title: PSTAT 5H Guest Lecture
text:
Sparsity
The mathematical form of the constraint includes an adjustable term \(\lambda\) that controls the strength of the constraint.

higher \(\lambda\) ➜ stronger constraint ➜ fewer variables selected
lower \(\lambda\) ➜ weaker constraint ➜ more variable selected
variable subsets are nested with \(\lambda\) : if \(\lambda_1 > \lambda_2\) then \(S_{\lambda_1} \subset S_{\lambda_2}\)


Think of \(\lambda\) as a volume knob that controls how many variables are selected.

title: PSTAT 5H Guest Lecture
text:
Model selection strategy
The ‘traditional’ approach to selection using regularization is this:

Use regularization for a sequence of \(\lambda_1 < \lambda_2 < \cdots < \lambda_K\) to obtain candidate linear models \(M_1 \supset M_2 \supset \cdots \supset M_K\)
Choose the candidate \(M^* \in \{M_1, \dots, M_K\}\) that gives the best predictions


However, this tends to over-select (too many variables).

title: PSTAT 5H Guest Lecture
text:
Network recovery
The same techniques can recover networks from time series:


network describes evolution in time
sparse because there are few connections

title: PSTAT 5H Guest Lecture
text:
Innovations
I work on methodology for improved selection. So far I’ve used two ‘tricks’ in combination:

computationally intensive approach: subsample data and do many repetitions to find ‘stable’ subsets
aggregation: combine multiple models instead of selecting just one


Benefits:

sparser networks with comparable predictive power
finer control over selection behavior using algorithm parameters

title: Interval estimation
text:
Today’s goal
Introduce interval estimation – estimating a parameter by a range of values (e.g., 1.18 – 2.36) instead of a single value (e.g., 2.21).

Key concepts:

interval estimate
coverage
width and uncertainty

title: Interval estimation
text:
Motivating example



Question


How hard is it to juggle \(K\) objects?




If the general population can typically manage at most \(\theta\) objects:

larger numbers \(K >\theta\) are hard
smaller numbers \(K < \theta\) are easy

title: Interval estimation
text:
What’s typical?
A few common ways to define the “typical number”:

(\(\theta\) = population mean) the average number the general population can juggle
(\(\theta\) = population median) the ‘middle’ number the general population can juggle





Terminology


These are examples of different population parameters.

title: Interval estimation
text:
Estimation
It’s cumbersome, if not impossible (and not to mention pointless), to find and ask every human being how many objects they can juggle.

So practically speaking, \(\theta\) cannot be determined exactly; instead it is estimated from a sample of people representative of the general population.

a point estimate is a single value – one “best guess”
an interval estimate is a range of values – many plausible options

title: Interval estimation
text:
Terminology and notation

\(f(x)\) is the distribution of population values



\(\theta\) is a population parameter of interest, i.e., an “estimand”
\(X_1, \dots, X_n\) are observations for a random sample of \(n\) individuals
\(\hat{\theta}\) is an “estimator” of the population parameter

title: Interval estimation

Helpful and unhelpful intervals
If we say that the average number of objects the general population can juggle is between 0 and 10 objects…

almost certainly correct
but not informative


If on the other hand we say 1.3-1.4…

informative estimate
but more likely to be mistaken



So just how wide should we make the interval?

title: Interval estimation
text:
Interval estimates



Concept


An interval estimate is a range of values for a population parameter.









Two hypothetical intervals – interval 1 covers the parameter and interval 2 misses.

title: Interval estimation
text:
Sampling variation
Even though estimates are pretty similar (and also close to \(\theta\)!) for most samples, they do move around a little.















Idea


What if instead of a single best guess, we calculated a range based on how much we sampling variation we expect in the point estimate?

title: Interval estimation
text:
Constructing intervals
A general method of construction for an interval estimate is:

start with a point estimate \(\hat{\theta}\)
based on its sampling distribution, choose an appropriate \(a, b\) and compute
\[
(\hat{\theta} - a, \hat{\theta} + b)
\]





Terminology


If \(a = b\), we say the interval is symmetric.

title: Interval estimation
text:
Interval coverage
We should be able to say how often a particular method of interval estimation produces a ‘correct’ result. This is known as “coverage”.




Key concept


The coverage of an interval estimator is the proportion of samples for which the interval covers the population parameter.





So if an interval has a coverage of 0.86, that means that the method by which it was constructed produces a ‘correct’ result (i.e., covers \(\theta\)) for 86% of samples.





Terminology


Statisticians equate coverage with the degree of confidence they have in their estimates: if an interval covers 86% of samples, then we can be 86% confident it is correct. For this reason the coverage is often called a confidence level.

title: Interval estimation
text:
Coverage
We should be able to say how often a particular method of interval estimation produces a ‘correct’ result. This is known as “coverage”.




Key concept


The coverage of an interval estimator is the proportion of samples for which the interval covers the population parameter.





So if an interval has a coverage of 0.86, that means that the method by which it was constructed produces a ‘correct’ result (i.e., covers \(\theta\)) for 86% of samples.

title: Interval estimation
text:
Interval for the mean



Problem statement


Based on the sample mean \(\hat{\theta}\), can we find a symmetric interval for the population mean \(\theta\) that achieves a coverage of \(1 - \alpha\)?




The classical solution is based on the \(T\) statistic \(T(\hat{\theta}) = \frac{\hat{\theta} - \theta}{SE(\hat{\theta})}\).

\(T(\hat{\theta})\) has a \(t_{n - 1}\) sampling distribution (approximately)
\(P(-t^{\alpha/2} < T(\hat{\theta}) < t^{\alpha/2}) = 1 - \alpha\) for \(t\)-quantiles \(t^{\alpha/2}\)






Reminder


A standard error is an estimate of the standard deviation of the sampling distribution. For the sample mean, \(SE(\hat{\theta}) = \sqrt{S^2/n}\).

title: Interval estimation
text:
Interval interpretation



Terminology


Statisticians equate coverage with the degree of confidence they have in their estimates: if an interval covers 86% of samples, then we can be 86% confident it is correct.
For this reason interval coverage is more commonly called a confidence level.



The standard interval interpretation is:

With \(100\times (1 - \alpha)\%\) confidence, the population mean is estimated to be between \(\hat{\theta}_{LO}\) and \(\hat{\theta}_{HI}\).

title: Interval estimation
text:
A design principle: coverage
We should be able to say how often a particular method of interval estimation produces a ‘correct’ result. This is known as “coverage”.




Key concept


The coverage of an interval estimator is the proportion of samples for which the interval covers the population parameter.





So if an interval has a coverage of 0.86, that means that the method by which it was constructed produces a ‘correct’ result (i.e., covers \(\theta\)) for 86% of samples.

title: Interval estimation
text:
Interval for the mean
The event that the \(T\) statistic is between two quantiles is equivalent to the event that the population parameter is covered by the endpoints:
\[
-t^{\alpha/2} < \underbrace{\frac{\hat{\theta} - \theta}{SE(\hat{\theta})}}_{T(\hat{\theta})} < t^{\alpha/2}
\quad\Longleftrightarrow\quad
\underbrace{\hat{\theta} - t^{\alpha/2} SE(\hat{\theta})}_{\hat{\theta} - a} < \theta < \underbrace{\hat{\theta} + t^{\alpha/2} SE(\hat{\theta})}_{\hat{\theta} + b}
\]

So the probabilities are also equal and therefore:
\[
P\left(\hat{\theta} - t^{\alpha/2} SE(\hat{\theta}) < \theta < \hat{\theta} + t^{\alpha/2} SE(\hat{\theta})\right) = 1 - \alpha
\]


In other words, the interval \(\hat{\theta} \pm t^{\alpha/2}SE(\hat{\theta})\) covers \(\theta\) with probability \(1 - \alpha\).

title: Interval estimation
text:
Calculating intervals




x

 [1] 1 4 2 0 3 5 0 1 4 2 2 2 0 2 3 2 1 1 1 1 2 1 2 3 1 2 0 0 3 0 2 1 2 3 2 0 0 4
[39] 2 4 2 0 3 1 3 4 2 0 2 0


These intervals are easy to compute:

Calculate the sample mean \(\hat{\theta}\)and the sample variance \(S^2\)

c(mean(x), var(x))

[1] 1.760000 1.777959


Compute \(SE(\hat{\theta}) = \sqrt{\frac{S^2}{n}}\)

sqrt(var(x)/n)

[1] 0.1885714


Find the \(t^{\alpha/2}\) quantile (with \(n - 1\) degrees of freedom)

qt(0.025, df = n - 1, lower.tail = F)

[1] 2.009575


Calculate the interval

c(1.76 - 2.01*0.189, 1.76 + 2.01*0.189)

[1] 1.38011 2.13989

title: Interval estimation
text:
Comparing coverages

Calculated intervals with two coverages – 50% intervals (left) and 80% intervals(right).

title: Interval estimation
text:
Incorrect interpretation



Common mistake


It is not accurate to say \(\theta\) is between the endpoints with probability \(1 - \alpha\).




Why not? Because \(\theta\) is a parameter, not a random variable.


\(P(1.13 < \theta < 2.21)\) is nonsense, because nothing in \(P(\cdot)\) is probabilistic.


It’s easy to get mixed up because \(P(\hat{\theta}_{LO} < \theta < \hat{\theta}_{HI})\) is well-defined: the endpoints are random functions of data. But as soon as specific numbers are calculated, there’s no longer a well-defined probability.

title: Interval estimation
text:
Audience and background
Audience: undergraduate students taking a first course in statistics.

Possible texts: Using R for Introductory Statistics by John Verzani; Introductory Statistics with Randomization and Simulation by Diez et al.


Prior sessions: we would have already covered…

sampling concepts and inferential thinking
elementary data visualizations and summary statistics
point estimation for the mean and variance
sampling distributions

title: Interval estimation
text:
Interval width



Uncertainty quantification


The width of an interval conveys the degree of uncertainty associated with an estimate.



The width of the interval for the mean is:
\[
\left[\hat{\theta} + t^{\alpha/2} SE(\hat{\theta})\right] - \left[\hat{\theta} - t^{\alpha/2} SE(\hat{\theta})\right]
= 2t^{\alpha/2}SE(\hat{\theta})
= 2\times t^{\color{maroon}{\alpha/2}}\times \sqrt{\frac{\color{purple}{S^2}}{\color{teal}{n}}}
\]

What do you think will happen if we…

lower the coverage? (hint: already saw this)
collect more data?
sample from a population with more variability?

text:
Checking our answers

Change sample sizeChange population variance

title: Interval estimation
text:
Takeaways

Interval estimates are a range of values rather than a single number.
Constructed from a point estimator and knowledge of its sampling distribution.
Interval estimators are constructed to achieve a specified coverage: proportion of samples for which the interval includes the population parameter.
Given a fixed coverage, the width of an interval communicates the degree of uncertainty about the estimate.

title: Interval estimation
text:
Point estimation
Often \(\hat{\theta}\) is simply the sample analogue of \(\theta\): for instance, as we saw before, the sample mean is a point estimator of the population mean.

Estimate of the population mean (left) using the sample mean (right) of 50 independent observations.

title: Interval estimation
text:
Next time: bootstrapping
Perhaps you thought that estimating the mean number of objects one can juggle is not the best way to determine what’s challenging or easy.

Why not estimate, e.g., the 95th percentile?
There is a sampling distribution for sample quantiles, but it’s a bit hairy to work out.


Bootstrapping provides a theory-free method of interval estimation for arbitrary population parameters.
